description: Home to the oldest geological society in the world, founded in 1807. The Society has been based at Burlington House since 1874, and now has over 12,000 members worldwide.

designers.architect: Robert Richardson Banks and Charles Barry

factsheet.heading: Welcome to the Geological Society
paragraphs: We are the UK’s professional body and learned society for geoscience and the oldest geological society in the world.
We support and inform scientists and the general public, primarily by helping to improve knowledge and understanding of geoscience and promoting professional excellence and ethical standards
Founded in 1807, we have been in our present home in Burlington House since 1874.

factsheet.heading: What's on view
paragraphs: On your visit you will see: Entrance Hall, in which is displayed the first geological map of England & Wales (1815) by William Smith and a painting of palaeontologist Mary Anning; the triple and double tiered Upper and Lower Libraries which hold the Society’s internationally important collections; the Council Room with portraits of a number of the Society’s major historical figures; our modern Lecture Theatre.

factsheet.heading: Children's Activities - no booking required
paragraphs: We will be running educational activities throughout the day - just pop in!
(Example activities from 2024. 2025 activities to be confirmed)

Curious about rocks in space? Get up close with meteorites and learn more about planetary geoscience. See if you can become a meteorite expert!  
 
2. Rock Pets
Get creative and bring to life your very own rock pet! Unleash your inner artist to transform ordinary rocks into exciting pets to take home!

factsheet.heading: Children's Activities - booking essential
paragraphs: See timings and how to book under Activities

Join Dr Lucia Perez-Diaz, Earth scientist and author-illustrator of How the Earth Works, for a fun-filled journey through our planet’s past, present, and future! After a short, interactive reading, kids will hunt for tectonic puzzle pieces hidden around the venue and work together to rebuild Earth and learn how plate tectonics shapes the world around us. Explore ancient supercontinents and imagine the Earth to come—all in one afternoon! Ages 7–10.
Event 2 – Time Travellers of Planet Earth

Travel through time with Dr Lucia Perez-Diaz, author of How the Earth Works! Dinosaurs, volcanoes, ice ages and more await in this interactive event for curious 7–10 year olds. Children will be introduced to the secret ingredient behind all life as we know it: plate tectonics, and work together to reconstruct a timeline of Earth's fascinating past. The adventure ends with a creative draw-along—imagining what Earth looked like millions of years ago, and dreaming up what it might look like in the future!

factsheet.heading: About Burlington House
paragraphs: The original Burlington House was built by Sir John Denham for his new bride in 1665 but after her early death it was sold to Richard Boyle, first Earl of Burlington, in 1668. Between 1715-1722, the third Earl had the house reconstructed in the Palladian style which we see today. The property then passed to the Cavendish family in the mid 18th century and was eventually purchased by the Government in 1854 with the express purpose of housing the learned societies close to the Royal Academy to encourage interchange between the arts and sciences. Additional accommodation was provided in the West and East wings and gateway blocks enclosing the courtyard, which were completed to the designs of architects Charles Barry and Robert Richardson Banks between 1869-1873. The exterior of the Grade II* listed building is of Portland Stone (Upper Jurassic). The Society's apartments have undergone a number of refurbishments over the years, most recently from 2007-2013.

factsheet.heading: Photography
paragraphs: Visitors are welcome to photograph inside the Society's apartments for their own personal use. No flash photography or tripods please.

name: Burlington House: The Geological Society of London
